channel.title: Twilight (Movie)
channel.description:
I know we have a "Twilight Series" thread- but that's based on the books. This is about the movie.
I just watched it (not illegally, how dare you make such accusations :|) - and if i were to rate it as an overall, I'd give it a 4. Did not like it at all. No justice to the books, and found it completely boring, to be honest.
I'm a late reader of the series, only started to see what the fuss was about. Finished the first book today, which I loved, and went to watch the movie and it didn't even feel like the books did. It felt very rushed, so much was left out and the theme of the books, being all vampire-ish, didn't feel that way at all.
If they had filmed for longer, or story boarded for longer, I believe it could have been a lot better. The music didn't suit the scenes and there was no suspense. The actors weren't to crash hot, either (Emotion, please?). Could have been a better cast.
That's my opinion. Seeing it again at the Theaters on Monday, so we'll see how I feel a second time 'round- Unless I fall asleep.
What say you?
http://www.evliving.com/2008/12/06/1867/twilight-movie-review/

item.title: Twilight (Movie)
item.dc:creator: @Full_Metalst Full Metalst
item.description:
@Full_Metalst wrote:

[quote=“cooper, post:34, topic:250308”][quote author=Full Metalst link=topic=330110.msg2876713#msg2876713 date=1248097276]

Any fucking Vampire that sparkles = not a vampire.

If you read the BOOK (my mom did, I get all the information from her), the author was meant for it to be different (wow forgot the name :()

What?

The author wanted the movie and book to be different. I get all the book information from my mom. Oops, sorry, “mum”.
[/quote]
Oh, I didn’t know that. Why did you add the part about using “mum” instead of mom?
Also, slightly interesting:
http://shelf-life.ew.com/2009/07/15/twilight-comic-book-manga/[/quote]
I said “mum” for all the Brits, since they love messing with us Americans… Just skip the subject that I said mum.

Read full topic

item.description:
@PeterMan wrote:

After all I have heard about Twilight, I’m not gonna go watch it. Sounds like shit.

I remember seeing this movie on TV last year or something, was really interesting consider it was done without speech: http://video.google.com/videoplay?docid=-6185283610506001721

EDIT: [quote=“T4_, post:28, topic:250308”]Nosferatu[/quote]

I didn’t notice that, but it must have gotten in my head somehow.

EDIT2: Crap, now I’m finding myself wanting to watch Nosferatu again. Well here goes :o

item.title: Twilight (Movie)
item.dc:creator: @Yeh Yeh
item.description:
@Yeh wrote:

I saw the movie without reading books and it was so-so. Ok, no, it sucked. Now I wonder if books are better and if it’s worth to read them - any suggestions? I agree with a need for acting lessons - for both of leading actors. Both of them were wooden - and I just didn’t see the romance, there was not much chemistry between them and it all seemed very awkward. Hopefully next movie will be better. And they need to recast Jacob Black, seriously. That kid can’t act.

Read full topic

item.title: Twilight (Movie)
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

In movies you can’t really take time to introduce all characters properly, as most people just want 2-3 hours of action/romance/comedy/etc. That’s why I prefer a good series (like house, or CSI: Miami) over a good movie. There are quality movies, but after 2 hours they are done. In series they take time to expand the characters, although some series take it into surrealism sometimes.

The ultimate form of quality entertainment is a book, as it stimulates your brain to form an image of characters and scenes.

Read full topic

item.title: Twilight (Movie)
item.dc:creator: @XxKanexX Kane.
item.description:
@XxKanexX wrote:

[quote=“haticks, post:14, topic:250308”][quote author=Kane. link=topic=330110.msg2584592#msg2584592 date=1229408782]

I think, many people tend to get bored in longer movies, so that’s why they shortened it.

And sacrificed almost the entire back story, important parts and scenes that lacked… EVERYTHING.
The “Bella” character needs some acting lessons. Before starting the second movie she needs to grow a personality and emotions.
[/quote] Isn’t she awkward like that in the book though…I never read the book, but the movie sucked.[/quote]
Not really awkward, just quiet. She enjoys silence. But every scene seemed awkward in the movie. It was like they were all thinking “shit, is it my line next?”

[quote=“R.I.P RSC, post:13, topic:250308”][quote author=Kane. link=topic=330110.msg2584592#msg2584592 date=1229408782]

I think, many people tend to get bored in longer movies, so that’s why they shortened it.

And sacrificed almost the entire back story, important parts and scenes that lacked… EVERYTHING.
The “Bella” character needs some acting lessons. Before starting the second movie she needs to grow a personality and emotions.
[/quote]

Movies are made for the big public. Fans of the books don’t like it, but the money isn’t coming from the fans, it’s coming from the big crowd. So they have to make a commercial success. Which also makes most movies boring, inaccurate, and not to the likings of the original authors and true fans.

I suggest to watch opera’s instead. That’s where you’ll find quality.[/quote]
That is quite true. Although, I bet it would be a much better success if it stuck to the story and seemed a lot more interesting to those who haven’t read the book; then they may read it- or I’d go see it again.

Benz:

I agree with the necessity of the acting lessons, Kane. I started reading the book; on chapter 6 right now. The book is better than the movie so far.

It gets a lot better. The start is all the introduction and explanations, the middle and end is where everything gets good.

Read full topic
